citeinfo.title: Golden Eagle Food Habits in the Mojave Desert: Remote nest camera data

descript.abstract: Expansion of renewable energy development is rapidly transforming the Mojave Desert landscape and has the potential to impact Golden Eagles through loss of foraging habitat and reduced prey base. Regional information on Golden Eagle food habits is limited and little is known of how dietary variability influences eagle productivity. We examined diet using motion activated trail cameras and collection of prey remains at 18 nests during two seasons (2014 and 2015).
descript.purpose: To provide baseline diet information to inform regional conservation strategies.
descript.supplinf: Nest Cameras: We used historical geospatial nest information compiled from interagency databases (USFWS, BLM, CDFW, and NDOW) to target known breeding areas within the Mojave Desert eco-regions of Nevada and California during two nesting seasons (2014 and 2015). For nests determined to be active, we installed cameras when nestlings reached greater than or equal to 3.5 weeks of age. The timing of camera installation was intended to minimize disturbance of breeding activities (in accordance with USFWS permit #MB27836B-0). Adults are most susceptible to disturbance during the earliest stages of nesting and chicks, which cannot thermoregulate prior to 3 weeks of age, are at risk of mortality if exposed to prolonged cold or heat. We used trail cameras manufactured by Bushnell (Trophy Cam, 8 megapixel) and Reconyx (HC500, 3.1 megapixel). Each camera was equipped with lithium ion AA batteries and a 32 gigabyte SD memory card. Cameras were programed to take one picture when movement was detected at minimum intervals of 60 seconds. For each prey delivery captured by nest cameras, we recorded the date and time the photograph was taken, as well as the prey species and the estimated percent of the item delivered. For example, the lower half of a black-tailed jackrabbit would be estimated as 50% of the whole individual. When possible, we recorded the age of individuals to increase the accuracy of biomass calculations. We calculated frequency of occurrence (percent composition) of prey in the diet by dividing the number of individuals for each species or category (i.e., leporids, birds, reptiles, mesocarnivores, and rodents) by the total number of individuals in the sample. To calculate biomass, we multiplied the number of individuals by the estimated weight of each species,

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

attr.attrdef: Larger group to which the animal belongs

edom.edomvd: The Leporidae are a family of mammals that include rabbits and hares, over 60 species in all.

A mesocarnivore is an animal whose diet consists of 50–70% meat with the balance consisting of non-vertebrate foods which may include fungi, fruits, and other plant material. Mesocarnivores are seen today among the Canidae (coyotes, many foxes), Viverridae (civets), Mustelidae (martens, tayra), Procyonidae (ring-tailed cat), Mephitidae (skunks), and Herpestidae (some mongooses).

attr.attrdef: The percent of the total diet for each prey species.
the percent of the total diet for each prey species
The frequency of prey species detected for both years compined.
The precent of the total diet for each prey species for both years combined.

overview.eaover: The entity and attribute information provided here describes the tabular data associated with the data set. distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected.
